State Key Laboratory of Pollution Control and Resource Reuse College of Environmental Science and Engineering Tongji University 1239 Siping Road Shanghai 200092 China Graphical abstract Metal-organic framework derived materials have a great promise as non-precious metal-based electrocatalysts for large-scale applications of energy storage and transition devices with low-cost and high efficiency. Here, we report a high performance core-shell-structured nitrogen-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/reduced graphene oxide (rGO) hybrid, which is derived from Fe-doped Co3[Co(CN)6]2 MOFs, as bifunctional catalysts for both oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Structure characterizations show that the carbon shell of CoCx/FeCo and graphene support are bonded to each other, which offer a large surface area and stable anchoring sites for the CoCx/FeCo. Electrochemical tests show that N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO hybrid exhibits superior onset potential (1.0183 V vs RHE), half-wave potential (0.9653 V vs RHE), peak current intensity (0.9233 mA/cm−2) and long-term durability for ORR than those of Pt/C (onset potential, half-wave potential and peak current intensity are 1.0174 V and 0.9213 V, 0.8233 mA/cm−2, respectively) in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. The overpotential of the hybrid for OER is only ∼390 mV at a current intensity of 10 mA/cm−2, which is close to that of the RuO2. The excellent electrocatalytic properties of this hybrid make it a great potential to be substitute for precious-based catalysts for ORR and OER in fuel cells and water splitting. Keywords Metal-organic framework Nitrogen-doped core-shell Bifunctional Electrocatalysts Oxygen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction 1 Introduction Oxygen electrochemistry, such as oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), is the key process in electrochemical energy storage and energy conversion applications, such as fuel cells, regenerative metal-air batteries and supercapacitors [1–4]. Highly stable and efficient electrocatalyst in the electrode is critical for these technologies [5]. However, the sluggish kinetics of noble precious metal-based catalysts for ORR and OER become one of major technical barriers for the development and real applications of these technologies [6–8]. Despite the noble metal oxides (like RuO2 and IrO2) and noble metals (such as Pt) as the state-of-the-art catalysts for OER and ORR, the shortcomings of poor stability, high cost, rare source, easily poisoning and sluggish activity are still the major obstacles for their large-scale applications [9–12]. Thus, developing highly efficient, low-cost and highly durable catalyst for OER and ORR is in great demand. Recent studies have shown that a wide range of novel materials, including metal oxides, carbides, nitrides, sulfides and nanocarbons, have excellent electrochemical catalytic performance [13–17]. For instance, nanocarbon-based materials, such as carbon nanotube, graphene, etc., can improve the catalytic performance and long-time running stability of other catalysts through structural tuning and synergistic effects between each components [18]. In particular, the improved performance of graphene-based composite catalysts was attributed to the structural defect of graphene and the synergistic effect between graphene and the matrix catalysts [19–21]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs)-derived carbon-based functional materials have been reported as catalysts for ORR [22]. But the structures of the MOFs are prone to be collapsed in the annealing process, resulting to a bulk phase with the absence of porous structure, which reduces the electrochemical activity of MOFs [23,24]. What’s more, the existence of abundant carbon and nitrogen species not only influences the structure of the material but also improves the catalytic performance. The doped nitrogen atoms serve as heteroatoms in the N-doped materials, which make the major contribution for the enhanced electrocatalytic performances for the ORR and OER [25]. However, due to the low graphitization degree, the electron transfer ability of the MOFs-derived carbon materials is weak. Although a large amount of MOFs-derived nanomaterials have been reported as electrocatalysts for ORR and OER, the electrocatalytic property still can’t be satisfied [26]. Reduced graphene oxide (rGO), with large specific surface area and good electrical conductivity, has been reported as an active support, recently. The rGO supported MOFs-derived materials have been attracted great attention due to the improved electrocatalytic activity [27,28]. In this work, we synthesized core-shell-structured nitrogen-doped CoCx/FeCo@C hybrid supported on reduced graphene oxide sheets (N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO) by a facile pyrolysis process using graphene oxide (GO) and Co3[Co(CN)6]2 as precursors. The catalytic performances of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO for ORR and OER in alkaline electrolyte were investigated. The rGO supported core-shell structured N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO exhibits much higher electrocatalytic activity, long-time running stability than the benchmark Pt/C catalysts for ORR under the same working conditions. On the other hand, the hybrid also shows higher catalytic performance for OER compared with the RuO2. On the one hand, renewable fuel cell can be used as an efficient energy conversion device with the consumption of hydrogen and the reverse process is an important way to generate hydrogen and oxygen. Therefore, bifunctional catalyst for both ORR and OER which can be used in this system is in need. Compared to the reported high activity ORR and OER catalysts, the synthesis of this catalyst has the following characteristics: during the annealing process, the alloy interacts with the carbon shell which derived from the MOFs to generate the metal carbides. The synergistic effect between the alloy and the metal carbides, carbon shell and the rGO, promote the activity of ORR and OER. The structure where the core shell and the graphene coexist provides a larger specific surface area for the reaction and increases more active sites. The work proves that the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO is a promising bifunctional catalyst for ORR and OER. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials synthesis Graphene oxide (GO) solution was prepared from natural graphite by a modified Hummers’ method, which had been reported before [59]. Except for the GO solution, all the other reagents were analytic purity grade and used without any treatments. 2.1.1 Preparation of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO First, 0.3323 g potassium cobalticyanide (K3[Co(CN)6]) and 0.4 g polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) were dissolved into 10 ml DI water and form a transparent solution. The mixture was magnetically stirred for 0.5 h at room temperature. Then, 10 ml 1 M cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate (Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O) was slowly added into the solution with stirring, and the mixture turned to pink when aged at room temperature without stirring for 12 h. After that, 10 ml 0.5 M ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O) solution was dropped in with stirring and the color of the obtained solution turned orange immediately. The obtained orange solution was stirred for 15 h and the color of the solution turned into dark yellow. Then 5 ml GO (6 g/l) solution was dropped into the dark yellow solution and stirred for another 1 h and followed with sonication for 1 h. Finally, we got a dark yellow precipitate when the solution was silently deposited. The obtained precipitate was moved into a ceramic crucible after thoroughly washed with DI water and heat-treated at 800 °C for 4 h in argon (Ar) atmosphere. The final obtained black powder was N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO. 2.1.2 Preparation of FeCo@NC 0.1662 g K3[Co(CN)6] and 0.3 g PVP were first dissolved in 10 ml DI water which followed by stirring for 0.5 h at room temperature. Then, 5 ml 1 M Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O was gently dropped in the mixture under constant stirring for 4.5 h to make a pink solution. After that, 10 ml 0.5 M FeCl3·6H2O was dropped in and followed with stirring for 20 h to make a dark yellow solution. After that, the dark yellow precipitate was fully washed with DI water and dried in vacuum oven at 60 °C for 12 h. At last, the obtained powder was heated to 800 °C and kept for 4 h in argon (Ar) atmosphere in a ceramic crucible. The final obtained black powder was FeCo@NC. 2.1.3 Preparation of CoCx@NC 0.1662 g K3[Co(CN)6] and 0.3 g PVP were first dissolved in 10 ml DI water which followed by stirring for 0.5 h at room temperature. Then, 5 ml 1 M Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O was gently dropped in the mixture under constant stirring for 4.5 h to make a pink solution. The obtained precipitate was dried in vacuum oven at 60 °C for 12 h. Then, the obtained powder was heated to 800 °C and kept for 4 h in argon (Ar) atmosphere in a ceramic crucible. The final obtained black powder was CoCx@NC. 2.2 Materials characterization The XRD data between 10° and 80° (2θ) were collected by a Bruker D8 advanced X-Ray diffractometer (XRD) with Cu-Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å). A HP 5950A ESCA spectrometer with Mg Kα source was used to collect the data of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). For XPS, the charge correction value of C 1s is 284.6 eV, which the instruments provide the same results with an error of 0.02 eV. The morphology of the catalysts was observed by a Hitachi (JSM-7610F) scanning electron microscope (SEM) with energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) and elemental mapping tests. The images from transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high resolution TEM (HRTEM) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) were collected on a Tecnai (20 U-TWIN) transmission electron microscope. The Raman spectra were obtained by a Renishaw inVia spectrometer with 532 nm laser excitation. N2 adsorption–desorption measurements were carried out at 77 K using a Quantachrome Autosorb gas-sorption system to determine the specific surface area. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements 5 mg catalyst was weighted and mixed with 50 μl Nafion solution (Aldrich, 5% in aliphatic alcohols) and 450 μl DI water. Then the mixture was sonicated for 40 min to form a uniform black ink. 5.0 μl of the ink was pipetted and dropped onto a glassy-carbon electrode, which had been polished to a mirror surface, and fully dried. The content of Pt in the commercial Pt/C catalyst is 20%. The electrochemical tests were conducted on a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation with a three-electrode cell system (a glassy carbon disk as working electrode, carbon electrode as the counter electrode and saturated Hg/Hg2Cl2 as the reference electrode) in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. For ORR, the 0.1 M KOH electrolyte was bubbled by Ar (argon) for 1 h with continuous stirring. Then the cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests were conducted in Ar-saturated electrolyte until stable results were obtained to remove the micro-amount of unstable materials from the binders and electrolyte. Then the CV tests were conducted in O2-saturated electrolyte with the sweep rate of 0.005 V/s and the results were recorded. The linear sweeping voltammetry (LSV), Tafel and chronoamperometric tests were conducted in O2-saturated electrolyte. Rotating disc electrode (RDE) tests were conducted with rotating speeds from 625 rpm to 2500 rpm with the same the sweeping rate of CV tests by using a RRDE-3A electrode. Rotating ring disc electrode (RRDE) tests were conducted at a rotating speed of 1600 rpm with the sweeping rate of 0.005 V/s. For OER, the 0.1 M KOH electrolyte was only bubbled by O2 for 1 h with continuous stirring. The LSV tests were conducted at a rotating speed of 1600 rpm with the sweeping rate of 0.005 V/s. Hereafter, the electrode potentials of all the tests are reported with the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) potential, which is converted from the Hg/Hg2Cl2 electrode using: E RHE = E (Hg/Hg2Cl2) + 1.0133 V [60]. 2.4 Computational method Based on the optimized unit cell of graphene, we built a graphene sheet with 12.29 Å for x-axis and 17.04 Å for y-axis containing 70 carbon atoms as the substrate. Then, Co, Fe atoms were introduced into graphene sheet. During all calculations, a 30 Å vacuum space along the z-axis was imposed to avoid interlayer interactions. Density Functional Theory (DFT) is a successful approach to describe the ground state properties of metals, semiconductors, and insulators. In this study, DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) computer code [61]. The spin polarized generalized gradient approximation (GGA) method of Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) were used to deal with the exchange-correlation functional by applying Ultra-soft Vanderbilt pseudopotential (USPP) [62,63]. The analysis of atomic charge was carried out by Bader [64]. The cutoff energy was set to 400 eV. The each model was fully relaxed until none of the residual forces acting on any atom exceeded 0.001 eV/Å with a 1 × 1 × 1 k-point grid. 3 Results and discussion The synthetic process of the catalyst was shown in Fig. 1 a. Fig. 1b and c showed the typical transmission electron microscopy (TEM) pictures of the obtained Fe-doped Co3[Co(CN)6]2 MOFs, which proved that the Fe-doped Co3[Co(CN)6]2 inherited the cubic structure of Co3[Co(CN)6]2 with an average length and width of ∼60 nm. The TEM images of Co3[Co(CN)6]2 was provided in the Fig. S1. The XRD patterns of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC are showed in Fig. 2 a. It was easily indexed that the diffraction peaks were corresponding to the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) No. 65-4131 of FeCo alloy and No. 44-0962 of CoCx, which confirmed the successful synthesis of FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC. The XRD pattern of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO showed the diffraction peaks of FeCo alloy and CoCx at the same time, which meant the successful synthesis of the hybrid. The inset was the partial enlarged XRD patterns, which were corresponding to (1 0 0) facet of FeCo alloy and (1 1 0) facet of CoCx, respectively. Compared with the XRD patterns of pure FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC, the diffraction peaks corresponding to (1 0 0) facet of FeCo alloy and (1 1 0) facet of CoCx of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO had slight shift, which should be attributed to the influences of the coexisted two phases and the N-doped rGO support [29]. The diffraction peak around 27° should be attribute to the (0 0 2) planes of rGO and the carbon shell [30]. The Raman spectra of the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC are shown in Fig. 2b, which is illustrated that the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, the G band is centered at 1598 cm−1, which is higher than that of the other two materials (1585 cm−1 for FeCo@NC, 1585 cm−1 for CoCx@NC). It’s little different from the reported result that the D band is centered around 1328 cm−1 and the G band is centered around 1580 cm−1, respectively [31]. On the other hand, the intensity ration of ID /IG of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO is 1.12 which is lower than that of FeCo@NC (1.41) and CoCx@NC (1.20). The calculated results indicates that the sp2 carbon atoms of the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO is increased [32]. The doped nitrogen atoms can enlarge the particles size and make the corresponding G peak shifted to higher wavenumber direction [33]. The results also demonstrate the successful doping of nitrogen atoms to rGO [34]. To further investigate the composition of the catalysts, the XPS tests were conducted. The full spectra of the XPS of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO are supplied in the Fig. S2a, which reveals the existence of C, O, N, Fe and Co elements in the hybrid. Fig. 2c–f shows the high-resolution XPS of C, N, Fe and Co, respectively. Fig. 2c shows the deconvoluted high-resolution spectra of C 1s. It is clearly showed the existence of CCo (284.16 eV), C 1s (284.58 eV), CO/CN (285.03 eV) and CO/CN (286.43 eV) bonds, respectively. The existence of CCo bond can be attributed to the CoCx in the hybrid [35]. The other two peaks with the binding energy of 285.03 eV and 286.43 eV should be attributed to CN bond and CO bond, which illustrate the successful doping of nitrogen. The oxygen maybe comes from the residue of raw materials or test environment contamination. Fig. 2d shows the high-resolution XPS of N 1s. The spectra can be deconvoluted into pyridinic-N (396.88 eV), pyrrolic-N (399.26 eV), graphitic-N (400.90 eV) and oxygenated-N (405.72 eV), respectively [36]. Based on XPS test, the atomic ratios of the catalysts are also obtained. Two peaks located at 708.79 and 722.69 eV can be derived from the binding energies of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 with satellite peaks located at 712.06 and 731.80 eV, respectively, implying the existence of Fe3+ species. The peak at 705.70 and 716.97 eV can be assigned to Fe0, which should be ascribed to the metallic Fe in FeCo alloy [65]. The deconvoluted peaks of Co atom should be assigned to three distinct chemical species, that is CoC (CoC 2p3/2 at 778.63 eV, CoC 2p1/2 at 796.23 eV, respectively), Co0 (Co 2p3/2 at 782.77 eV, Co 2p1/2 at 799.52 eV, respectively), and the satellite peaks (denoted as “sat”) in Fig. 2f. The deconvoluted high-resolution XPS of N, Fe and Co prove the successful synthesis of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO. The XPS of FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC are provided in Figs. S3 and S4, respectively. The XPS results prove the success synthesis of the catalysts. The performances of catalysts are usually greatly influenced by the specific surface area. The specific surface area of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC are examined and the results are supplied in Fig. S5, respectively. Results showed that the specific surface area of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC are 68.09, 16.07 and 38.65 m2/g respectively. The N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO showed a higher specific surface area than the FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC. The larger specific surface area of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO should be attributed to the existence of rGO support. The morphology of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC were further characterized by the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) tests. Fig. 3 a shows the morphology of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, which is clearly observed that a core-shell structure is formed. Comparison of Figs. 3a and 1c illustrated that the original cubic structure of the MOFs’ had been destroyed. The particle size of the obtained core-shell structure was about 100 nm that is larger than the matrix, which should be attributed to the aggregation and growth of the MOFs particles during the annealing process [37]. The Co3[Co(CN)6]2 particles played the role of templates as a self-assembled precursor in the reaction process. The CoCx was well wrapped by carbon membrane and formed a core-shell structure, which derived from the Co3[Co(CN)6]2 (Fig. S6a). The similar structure was also found in the SEM tests of FeCo@NC, as shown in Fig. S7a. The TEM tests of the particles in Fig. 3b showed a wrinkled structure, which should be attributed to the rGO support. TEM also clearly showed that the particles were evenly anchored on the rGO [38]. The elemental mappings of each catalyst are provided in Figs. S8–S10. Result shows that the total content of doped nitrogen of the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO reaches up to 3.0 at%. And the corresponding elemental distributions of all the catalysts were consistent with each other, which also proved the successful synthesis of catalysts [39]. Fig. 3c revealed that the CoCx/FeCo was covered by continuous carbon shell with different thickness, which could enhance the transfer of the intermediate of oxygen reduction [40]. The HRTEM images of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO (Fig. 3d) illustrated the lattice space of 0.201 nm and 0.208 nm, which matched well with the crystal facet parameter of FeCo (1 1 0) facet and CoCx (1 1 1) facet, respectively. The inset in Fig. 3b is the SAED test of CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, which clearly illustrates the existence of (1 1 0) of FeCo and (1 1 1) of CoCx planes. The results of SAED tests are consistent with the results of HRTEM tests. Both the SEM and TEM tests of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO clearly revealed the core-shell structure of the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO and supported by rGO sheets. The HRTEM and SAED images of CoCx@NC and FeCo@NC CoCx@NC are provided in the Figs. S6 and S7, respectively. The electrocatalytic performances of the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO for ORR were firstly investigated by the cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests in both O2- and Ar-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte at the sweeping rate of 0.005 V s−1 and the results are shown in Fig. 4 a. The CV tests of FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC are supplied in Fig. S11, respectively. Fig. 4a clearly reveals that there is no peak detected in the Ar-saturated electrolyte, which indicates that the catalyst has a high stability during the tests in the electrolyte. However, an obvious peak is observed in CV curve of the O2-saturated electrolyte, which should be attributed to the ORR that is catalyzed by N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO. Compared with the CV tests of FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC in figure, it could be found that the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO shows the highest peak current intensity among all the catalysts, which even surpasses the reported Pt/C catalyst [41]. The outer carbon shell of the catalysts influenced the catalytic performance [42]. The onset potential and peak current intensity of ORR with the catalysis of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO is also higher than that of FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC. This should be attributed to the different electron transfer characteristics of different carbon shell structure. On the other hand, the synergistic effect between the FeCo alloy and the nitrogen-doped CoCx also promote the happening of ORR [43]. The linear sweeping voltammetry (LSV) measurements are also conducted in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte at the rotating speed of 1600 rpm with a sweeping rate of 0.005 V s−1 and the results are showed in Fig. 4b (The LSV tests without rotation are shown in Fig. S11c). The N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO showed the highest current intensity and onset potential among all the catalysts. The improvement of the peak current intensity could be attributed to the enhanced catalytic characteristics of the different composition. The doped nitrogen of rGO and carbon shell can also play the role on improving the catalytic performance for ORR [44]. The onset potential for ORR of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO is 1.0183 V (vs RHE) and half-wave potential is 0.9653 V (Fig. S12), which was more positive than that of FeCo@NC (0.9583 V), CoCx@NC (0.9083 v) and Pt/C (1.0174 V). The half-wave potential of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO was 44 mV higher than that of the commercial Pt/C (0.9213 V) catalyst. The N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO also showed sharper current intensity growth trend in the mixed kinetic and diffusion-controlled zone than Pt/C catalyst, which also demonstrated the higher catalytic activity of for N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO ORR [45]. Compared with the other related catalysts (Table S3), the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO showed the best catalytic kinetics. The catalytic performance of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO for ORR was also examined by Tafel tests and the results are showed in Fig. 4c. It is clearly showed that the Tafel slope of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO is only 99.09 mV/dec, which is the lowest among all the three catalysts. The value is only a little higher than that of the Pt/C (73.05 mV/dec) catalyst [46]. The small Tafel slope indicates that the oxygen reduction with the catalysis of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO has a similar reaction mechanism with that of the Pt/C catalyst and the protonation process of O2 is the rate-determining step of ORR [47]. Based on the Tafel test, the exchange current intensity (i 0) and electron transfer coefficient (α) were calculated and the results are supplied in Table S1. The higher values of i 0 and α also proved that higher catalytic activity of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO. Fig. 4d illustrates the long-time running stability of the catalysts that were examined by the current-time chronoamperometric tests. It is clearly observed that the current intensity of all the catalysts slowly decreases with the time going on. After 5000 s, the current intensity of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO still remains 95.9%. It is not only higher than that of the other two catalysts but also higher than that of the Pt/C catalyst (74.3%). The slight decrease of the current intensity should be caused by the consumption of oxygen in the electrolyte [48]. The high long-time running stability of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO should be attributed to synergistic effect of nitrogen-doped graphene and the CoCx and FeCo alloy. On the other hand, the carbon shell can also inhibit the possible corrosion of the catalysts during the reaction process. The reaction mechanism of the catalysts for ORR is investigated by the RDE tests and the results are showed in Fig. 5 . Fig. 5a, b and e clearly showed the RDE tests of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC, and CoCx@NC. It is obvious observed that, to each catalyst, the current density increased with the increase of rotating speeds of electrode. This should be attributed to the shortened oxygen diffusion distance on the catalyst surface at high speed [49]. Based on the RDE tests, the corresponding Koutecky–Levich (K-L) plots were drawn and the results are showed in Fig. 5b, d and f, respectively. Fig. 5b, d and f magnified that, to each catalyst, the J −1 and ω −1/2 is in good linearity relationship, which means that the ORR on the electrode is the first-order reaction [50]. The electron transfer number of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC catalyzed ORR are calculated according to the Koutecky-Levich equation (Supplementary Material). And the results are displayed in Fig. 5b, d and f, respectively. It could be seen that the electron transfer number of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO is approach to 3.9, which means that the ORR major happened through 4-electron pathway. It was shown that the activities of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO form onset potential to peak potentialwas similar to that of the 20% Pt/C, which was consistent with the results of Fig. 4b. Compared with the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, the electron transfer number of FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC was about 3.7, which was a little lower than that of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO. This meant that N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO had a higher catalytic performance for ORR than FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC. The ORR major happened through the 4-electron and 2-electron pathways in the alkaline electrolyte [51]: (1) 4 - e l e c t r o n p a t h w a y : O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - → 4 OH - (2) 2 - e l e c t r o n p a t h w a y : O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 2 e - → 2 OH - + H 2 O 2 (3) H 2 O 2 + 2 e - → 2 OH - The N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO catalyzed ORR major through 4-electron pathway. In contrast, the FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC catalyzed ORR happened also through the mixed 4-electron and 2-electron pathways. The synergistic effect of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C and N-doped rGO sheets toward ORR improved the catalytic performance of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO. The interaction between MOFs-derived carbon and rGO decreases the electron-transfer resistance and provides more catalytic active sites [52]. The pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N plays a certain role on promoting the catalytic activity for ORR [53]. The electrocatalytic performances were also investigated by the rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) tests. Based on the RRDE tests, the electron transfer number (n) and the percentage of the generated hydrogen peroxide (H2O2%) of ORR were evaluated. Fig. 6 a showed the current intensity of disc electrode (Id ) and collection ring electrode of Pt (Ir ) of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC catalyzed ORR. Based on the RRDE tests, the electron transfer number and the percentage of H2O2 were calculated according to the Eqs. (4) and (5) [54]: (4) n = 4 × I d I d + I r / N (5) H 2 O 2 % = 200 × I r / N I d + I r / N where Id is the disk current, Ir is the ring current, and N is the geometrical current collection coefficient of the Pt ring in the RRDE (0.39). Fig. 6b showed that the calculated electron transfer number of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C was between 3.80 and 3.95, while that of the FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC were between 3.70–3.82 and 3.71–3.80, respectively. This result is consistent with the RDE test results. The percentages of H2O2 of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC are 8%, 12% and 15%, respectively. Based on the RDE and RRDE tests, it could be deduced that the 4-electron and 2-electron pathways for ORR coexisted [55]. The synergistic effect of rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx improved the catalytic performance of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO for ORR. The results suggest that FeCo alloy plays a crucial role in the electrocatalytic reaction, which the OO bond could break easily due to the strong binding affinity of Fe. On the other hand, the cobalt species in N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO also enhance the electron transfer ability, which finally improves the catalytic performance. What’s more, the CoCx/FeCo hybrid core has a strong electrochemical coupling effect with the N-doped carbon shell, which enhances the electron transfer and avoids the corrosion of CoCx/FeCo hybrids that contacts with large amounts of electrolyte [66]. The presence of rGO makes the hybrids distributed more uniformly, which increases the electrochemical active area and finally improves the electrochemical performance. Besides, the doped nitrogen is significant for the formation of defects, which enhances the excellent ORR performance [67]. The latter related DFT calculation will prove the role of the doped N. The synergistic effects of all the components in the catalyst promote the achievement of a high ORR catalytic activity in an alkaline electrolyte. The catalytic performence of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is also invastigated. The LSV and Tafel tests of OER were conducted by the rotating disk electrode tests in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte with a sweeping rate of 0.005 V/s at 1600 rpm. Fig. 7 a shows the LSV test results. As comparison, the LSV tests of both FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC are also provided. It is clearly showed that the onset potential of OER of FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC exhibit a low response with a high onset potential are 1.58 V and 1.59 V, respectively, while that of the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO renders is 1.55 V with high current intensity for OER. The potential of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC are 1.62 V, 1.71 V and 1.68 V, respectively. The over-potential of 10 mA/cm−2 is one of the criteria for judging the OER performance of the materials [56]. The over-potential of the OER of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO is only about 0.39 V (compared to the theoretical water oxidation equilibrium potential 1.23 V) at the current intensity of 10 mA/cm−2. But the over-potential of the FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC were 0.45 V and 0.48 V. Compared with the other related catalysts (Table S4), the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO showed the best catalytic kinetics, which even closed to the commercial RuO2 catalyst (over potential was 0.34 V). The N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGOshows the lowest potential among all the catalysts, which indicate the excellent OER catalytic performence of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO. The over-potential of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO for OER was lower than that of FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC. The N-doped rGO support also had a positive effect on the OER activity [57]. The wave of the LSV lines should be attributed to the oxygen bubbles on the electrode. Accompanied with the grown and broken away from the electrode of the oxygen bubbles, the catalytic active sites on the catalyst were blocked and exposed to the electrolyte at intervals. At the same time, the vigorous bubble formation on the electrode surface peels the catalysts off from the electrode. This is mainly responsible for the current decrease and instability of the curves. Fig. 7b showed the Tafel tests of the catalysts for OER. The lower tafel slope is also one of the important characterizations of catalysts. The Tafel slopes of the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC were only 77.1, 135.6 and 128.3 mV/dec, respectively. The Tafel slope of the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO was 77.1 mV/dec, which was quite approach to that of RuO2 (73.9 mV/dec). It is indicated that the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO shows the similar reaction mechanism with RuO2 [58]. Fig. 7c showed the durability tests of the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC on the rotating disk electrode (rotation speed 1600 rpm) at 1.60 V versus RHE in oxygen saturated 0.1 M KOH for 10 h. It was shown that the current density of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC, CoCx@NC and RuO2 decreased with a decay of 3.4%, 8.7%, 12.9% and 85.3%, respectively, after the i-t test at 10 mA/cm−2 in oxygen saturated 0.1 M KOH for 10 h. Due to the large amount of generated O2 bubbles on the electrode, the i-t curve appears to be floated up and down, which is a normal experimental phenomena. The LSV tests of the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO before and after the i-t measurements are shown in Fig. 7d. The LSV tests of the FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC before and after the i-t measurements are shown in Fig. S13. It is showed that the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO has a small current density attenuation, which is consistent with the small decay in i-t measurement. To investigate the theory for the catalytic performence of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC catalysts, the Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were conducted. By constructing a model to explore the active site, and then comparing with experimental results, the results can be drawn. After the N-doped on graphene sheets, according to the distance from Co to N atom, Co atom was adsorbed into two inequivalent sites, Co1 and Co2 as shown in Fig. 8 a, named CoCx@NC-1 and CoCx@NC-2. Based on FeCo@NC, same as CoCx@NC, we built five possible adsorption configurations for Co adsorption, named N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO. Then oxygen molecules (O2) were adsorbed on metal atoms by bridge mode as schemed in Fig. 8b. All the optimized structures are shown in Fig. S14. Bader charge analysis shows that the positive charge of metal atoms in FeCo@NC is higher than that of CoCx@NC. In N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, Co atomic charge remains basically unchanged, while Fe atom is significantly higher than that of FeCo@NC. Then enhanced positive charge of metal atoms would be more conducive to the adsorption of O2. Then we analyzed the charge transfer in O2 adsorbed hybrid and the data are available in Table S2. It can be seen that the amount of transferred charge from substrate to O2 is the highest in N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO, while that is the least in CoCx@NC. The more transferred charge is, the easier O2 dissociation is. To further confirm it, we analyzed the bond length of O2 adsorbed hybrid and found the bond length of O2 is the longest in N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO. The obtained data are shown in Table S2. As the result of increased charge transfer, the bond length of OO is increased, which suggest that the OO bond is more vulnerable to be destructed. Similarly, during the OER reaction, the length of OO adsorbed on the Co atom is decreased, which is more conducive to the evolution of oxygen. Therefore, the N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO shows better ORR and OER activity than that of FeCo@NC and CoCx@NC. 4 Conclusions In summary, a high-performance bifunctional electrocatalyst of N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO hybrid was developed. The special hetero-junction structure formed by the mutual connection of the core-shell-structured CoCx/FeCo@C and the rGO sheets gave a large surface area and stable activity sites for oxygen reduction and evolution. The N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO performed excellent catalytic activity for ORR with the onset potential (1.0183 V vs RHE) higher than Pt/C catalyst (1.0174 V vs RHE) and better long-time running stability. The N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO also exhibited remarkable electrocatalytic activity for OER, which had a low overpotential of ∼390 mV at 10 mA/cm−2 with Tafel slope of 74.1 mV/dec. The N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO shows great potential to be substitute for the precious-based catalysts for ORR and OER. This work offers a novel way to developing catalysts for ORR and OER with carbon and non-precious metal-based catalysts. Conflicts of interest There are no conflicts to declare. coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic framework derived materials have a great promise as non-precious metal-based electrocatalysts for large-scale applications of energy storage and transition devices with low-cost and high efficiency. Here, we report a high performance core-shell-structured nitrogen-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/reduced graphene oxide (rGO) hybrid, which is derived from Fe-doped Co3[Co(CN)6]2 MOFs, as bifunctional catalysts for both oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Structure characterizations show that the carbon shell of CoCx/FeCo and graphene support are bonded to each other, which offer a large surface area and stable anchoring sites for the CoCx/FeCo. Electrochemical tests show that N-doped CoCx/FeCo@C/rGO hybrid exhibits superior onset potential (1.0183 V vs RHE), half-wave potential (0.9653 V vs RHE), peak current intensity (0.9233 mA/cm−2) and long-term durability for ORR than those of Pt/C (onset potential, half-wave potential and peak current intensity are 1.0174 V and 0.9213 V, 0.8233 mA/cm−2, respectively) in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. The overpotential of the hybrid for OER is only ∼390 mV at a current intensity of 10 mA/cm−2, which is close to that of the RuO2. The excellent electrocatalytic properties of this hybrid make it a great potential to be substitute for precious-based catalysts for ORR and OER in fuel cells and water splitting.
coredata.dc:title: Metal-organic framework-derived core-shell-structured nitrogen-doped CoCx/FeCo@C hybrid supported by reduced graphene oxide sheets as high performance bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR and OER
